## Meeting Notes

### Velocity Systems’s Current Situation and Pain Points

- Starting point: blew past AutomateFlow usage limits during Black Friday spike in activity
- Company scaling rapidly but teams not growing at same pace
  - Manual processes becoming burden on teams
  - Roadblock to growth: could onboard 15-20 customers weekly vs current 5 if automated
- James brought on board to set up enterprise architecture in scalable way
- Currently have couple hundred customers, each with 5-500 customers of their own
- Scaling customer base from couple hundred to few thousand by end of year

### Current Tech Stack and Integration Requirements

- Core systems: SalesCloud (CRM), TaskBoard (likely PM choice), ChatSupport (ticketing), DataVault (data warehouse), TeamChat, Google Suite
- Currently using scattered approach: n8n, AutomateFlow, other ad hoc solutions across teams
- Moving away from every team doing what they want toward centralized approach
- Key integration needs:
  1. Bi-directional sync between SalesCloud and TaskBoard for custom fields/objects
    - Eliminate need for CSMs to go back and forth between systems
    - Tasks in TaskBoard should trigger SalesCloud actions and vice versa
  2. Bridge between ChatSupport and TaskBoard
    - Beyond native linking, need to manipulate objects from either side
    - Comments in TaskBoard should feed as chat messages to customers via ChatSupport
  3. Trigger-focused workflows through DataVault
    - Meta ads accounts: new leads flow into DataVault
    - When cost per lead exceeds threshold, create TaskBoard task for optimization
  4. Google Suite integrations
    - Calendar bookings trigger TaskBoard tasks
    - Automated emails

### Evaluation Criteria and Vendor Comparison

- Systems integration capability (not a concern - using standard tools)
- Depth of flexibility and robustness from trigger standpoint
  - Webhooks against specific events
  - Ability to trigger any/all events in platforms
- Infrastructure considerations: usage limits, pricing, reliability, uptime
- Security/compliance: GDPR and SOC compliant (required), HIPAA nice-to-have
- Guardrails and role profiles for future - don’t want open access infrastructure
- AI/agents nice-to-have but not priority (already have multiple AI solutions across teams)
- Technical team needs API flexibility for custom integrations
- Comparing primarily AutomateFlow vs IntegrateHub
  - Project management vendors defaulting to IntegrateHub for custom integrations
  - IntegrateHub quoted 250K actions per year (now using action-based pricing like AutomateFlow)

### Pricing and Timeline Discussion

- Current AutomateFlow usage: \~120K tasks, paying \~$10-20K/year
- Projected need: 250K-500K tasks maximum this year
- Self-serve pricing would be \~$22K/year at 500K tasks
- Enterprise plan: $50-100K/year range (includes account manager, support)
- IntegrateHub positioning enterprise features at team-level pricing
- Timeline: want decision locked down by March 1st, potentially faster
- February pilot: migrating 50-user team to new PM system with integrations

### Next Steps

- Alex: Send calendar invite for February 9th meeting
- Alex: Include Solutions Architect in next meeting
- Alex: Provide detailed pricing breakdown and ROI documentation
- Alex: Share head-to-head comparison rubric (AutomateFlow vs competitors)
- Alex: Follow up on potential earlier meeting slot next week
- James: Available February 9th-10th, also available before then if needed
- James: James review pricing/ROI materials and comparison rubric

activityLog.description: Discovery call with James Liao. Strong call - real pain, clear use cases, engaged champion. He's price-sensitive but not unreasonable. Main risk is IntegrateHub positioning enterprise features cheaper. March 1 decision deadline. Need to map economic buyer and justify enterprise pricing.

Sent follow-up email with: (1) Feb 9 meeting confirmed with SA, (2) AutomateFlow vs IntegrateHub comparison rubric, (3) Teams vs Enterprise framing ("platform access vs partnership"), (4) ROI calculator with use cases and value estimates (~$124K value vs $55K investment = 2.5x ROI). Framed metrics as primary, dollars as supporting. Link: https://example.com/...

James asked for filled-in comparison rubric (original was blank template). Created honest head-to-head assessment: AutomateFlow edge on 14 criteria, IntegrateHub on 6, 12 ties. Acknowledged IntegrateHub strengths (testing/deployment, complex orchestration, granular permissions, audit logging) while highlighting our advantages for their specific use case (usability, their stack compatibility, AI/BYOM, lower lock-in, incumbency). Sent standalone xlsx file.

doc_velocity-systems_will-governance-res.title: James-governance-response

doc_velocity-systems_will-followup-email.title: James-followup-email
doc_velocity-systems_will-followup-email.content:
Subject: Following up - AutomateFlow evaluation materials + Feb 9 meeting

Hi James,

Thanks for the conversation today. I have a much clearer picture of what you're building toward - centralizing your integration infrastructure as you scale from a couple hundred to a few thousand customers this year. That's a meaningful inflection point, and the work you're doing to set up the right architecture now James pay dividends.

A few things to share:

1. Feb 9 Meeting Confirmed

I've sent the calendar invite. I'm pulling in a Solutions Architect so we can get hands-on with your SalesCloud ↔ TaskBoard sync and the ChatSupport bridge use cases. We'll come prepared to talk through how we'd actually build these.

2. AutomateFlow vs IntegrateHub Comparison Rubric

Here's the evaluation framework we discussed: Comparison Rubric

This covers the criteria you mentioned - integrations, trigger flexibility, infrastructure, security/compliance, and support. I've tried to be honest about where each platform is stronger. You mentioned that PM vendors default to IntegrateHub for custom integrations - that's historically been true. IntegrateHub invested earlier in enterprise positioning. Our view is the platforms have converged significantly on capabilities, and the real differentiator is now the partnership model.

3. On Teams vs Enterprise Pricing

You asked a great question about the delta between self-serve Teams ($22K at 500K tasks) and Enterprise ($50K+). Here's how I'd frame it:

Teams plan = Platform access

You get the product

You figure out how to use it

Support is ticket-based

Good for: Teams that have in-house automation expertise and just need task capacity

Enterprise plan = Partnership

Dedicated Solutions Architect to help design and build

Customer Success Manager for ongoing optimization

Priority support with faster response times

Governance controls (SCIM, custom data retention, role restrictions)

Good for: Companies making AutomateFlow core infrastructure who need it to work reliably at scale

Given where you're headed - scaling from 200 to 2,000+ customers with teams that aren't growing proportionally - you're building on AutomateFlow as infrastructure, not just using it as a tool. The question is whether you want a partner in that or prefer to go it alone with more task capacity.

4. Use Case Assessment

I've documented the use cases we discussed with before/after metrics: Velocity Systems Value Assessment

Rather than put a dollar figure on everything (which can feel speculative), I've focused on the operational metrics that matter - context switches eliminated, response times improved, manual steps automated. We can refine these together on the 9th.

Let me know if you have questions before then, or if you want to move up the timeline.

Best,

Alex

doc_velocity-systems_moxie-platform-comp.title: Velocity Systems-platform-comparison-rubric
doc_velocity-systems_moxie-platform-comp.content: Category | Evaluation Criteria | AutomateFlow Assessment | IntegrateHub Assessment | Edge | Ease of Use & Adoption | Intuitive UI for business users (non-technical) | Strong. Visual canvas with drag-and-drop. No JSON required for standard workflows. 'Zap' metaphor is well-understood. | More technical. Recipe-based interface has steeper learning curve. Better for IT-led teams than business users. | AutomateFlow | Low/no-code capabilities | Core strength. Business users can build without engineering support. AI copilot assists with setup. | Requires more technical depth. 'Recipes' need understanding of data structures. Better suited for technical ops. | AutomateFlow | Learning curve / enablement time | Days to first value. Most users productive within 1 week. Extensive template library accelerates adoption. | Weeks to proficiency. More powerful but steeper ramp. Typically requires formal training. | AutomateFlow | Testing & Deployment Simplicity | Test button runs Zaps instantly. Versioning available on Enterprise. No staging environment. | Better here: Built-in versioning, staging environments, and deployment controls. More enterprise-grade. | IntegrateHub | Internal user feedback from pilot groups | TBD during February pilot - track adoption velocity and support tickets. | N/A - not piloting IntegrateHub. | TBD | Integration & Compatibility | Number of connectors / supported apps | 7,000+ app integrations. Broadest marketplace. Long tail of niche apps well-covered. | 1,000+ connectors. Fewer total but deeper enterprise app coverage (SAP, Workday, NetSuite). | AutomateFlow | Compatibility with Velocity Systems's stack (SalesCloud, TaskBoard, ChatSupport) | Native connectors for all three. SalesCloud trigger depth is strong. TaskBoard connector actively maintained. | Has all three but TaskBoard connector is newer. SalesCloud connector comparable. | AutomateFlow | Trigger diversity | Comprehensive triggers. Webhooks, scheduled, instant triggers. Paths for conditional logic. | Slightly more sophisticated event handling. Better at complex conditional triggers and polling intervals. | Tie | API flexibility / webhook support | Webhooks by AutomateFlow handles custom endpoints. API Request action for any REST API. | More powerful here: Custom SDK, on-prem agents, and deeper API customization options. | IntegrateHub | Performance & reliability of integrations | 99.9% uptime SLA on Enterprise. Some users report occasional delays on high-volume syncs. | Enterprise-grade reliability. Handles high-volume sync scenarios better historically. | Tie | Breadth of Stack Coverage | Better for SaaS-heavy stacks. Weaker on legacy/on-prem systems. | Stronger for hybrid environments with on-prem + cloud. Better ERP connectors. | AutomateFlow (for Velocity Systems's cloud stack) | Ecosystem Lock-in Risk | Low lock-in. Zaps are exportable. Skills transfer to any automation role. | Higher lock-in. Recipes require IntegrateHub-specific knowledge. Migration is harder. | AutomateFlow | Automation & AI Capabilities | Ability to orchestrate cross-tool workflows | Multi-step Zaps handle 100+ steps. Paths enable branching. Sub-Zaps for modularity. | More sophisticated orchestration. Better at complex multi-branch workflows with error handling. | IntegrateHub | Embedded AI features (content generation, summarization) | AI by AutomateFlow action for prompts. Native OpenAI, Claude, Gemini integrations. Copilot for building. | IntegrateHub AI capabilities less mature. Relies more on external AI tool integrations. | AutomateFlow | Reusability of workflows/templates | Shared folders on Teams+. Template library. Can duplicate and modify easily. | Better here: Callable recipes (like functions), more robust reusability patterns. | IntegrateHub | LLM Flexibility (OpenAI, Claude, Gemini, etc) | BYOM (Bring Your Own Model). Use your own API keys. No data passes through AutomateFlow. | Less flexible. More tightly coupled to specific AI partners. | AutomateFlow | Notification & alerting features | TeamChat, Teams, email, SMS integrations. Filter conditions for smart alerting. | Comparable alerting capabilities. Slightly better monitoring dashboards. | Tie | Scalability & Governance | Ease of scaling to additional teams | Teams/Enterprise: Shared workspaces, folders, permissions. Easy to add users and for those users to get up to speed | More robust multi-team governance. Better org hierarchy and workspace management, but higher learning curve | Tie | Permissions & role management | Enterprise: Admin, Member, Restricted roles. Folder-level permissions. SCIM provisioning. | More granular. Object-level permissions, custom roles, approval workflows. | IntegrateHub | Security & compliance (SOC 2, ISO, etc.) | SOC 2 Type II, GDPR, HIPAA eligible. Data encryption at rest and in transit. | SOC 2 Type II, ISO 27001, HIPAA. Comparable certifications. | Tie | Shareability/view access | Shared links for Zaps. View-only access available. Easy to share templates. | Better controlled sharing with approval workflows. | Tie | Admin & audit logging capabilities | Enterprise: Audit logs, data retention controls, usage reporting. | More comprehensive. Real-time activity streams, detailed audit trails. | IntegrateHub | Support & Services | Availability of implementation support / TAM | Enterprise: Dedicated CSM, Solutions Architect for implementation, TAM check-ins. | Similar model but often positioned at higher price points. | Tie | Responsiveness of support teams | Enterprise: <4hr response SLA. Priority queue. Direct TeamChat channel option. | Comparable SLAs. Strong support reputation. | Tie | Quality of documentation / onboarding | Extensive help docs, AutomateFlow University, YouTube tutorials. Very approachable. | Good docs but more technical. Less self-serve friendly for non-technical users. | AutomateFlow | In-house expertise (TAM, CAM, Solutions Architect) | Enterprise includes SA hours for building + ongoing TAM for optimization. | Similar model. May require higher tier for equivalent SA access. | AutomateFlow | Training resources for internal teams | AutomateFlow University free. Certification available. Extensive community. | Training available but less accessible. More formal training programs. | AutomateFlow | Strategic Fit | Flexibility to evolve with Velocity Systems's needs | Broad app coverage means new tools can be integrated quickly. AI focus aligns with market direction. | Strong for enterprise evolution. Better if Velocity Systems moves toward complex ERP/legacy integrations. | AutomateFlow (for current trajectory) | Product roadmap alignment | Heavy AI investment (Agents, AI actions, Copilot). Canvas redesign coming. Mobile app. | Enterprise workflow focus. Less visible on AI roadmap. | AutomateFlow | Vendor's willingness to co-develop / respond to feedback | Feature requests via community. Enterprise customers get product feedback sessions. | More white-glove for large deals. Custom development possible at high tiers. | Tie | Internal stakeholder preference / trust | James has existing AutomateFlow familiarity. Team knows the product. Lower change management. | Unknown. PM vendors (TaskBoard, Monday) default recommend IntegrateHub - creates anchoring. | AutomateFlow (incumbency) | SUMMARY | AutomateFlow Edge | 14 criteria | IntegrateHub Edge | 5 criteria | Tie/TBD | 13 criteria | KEY INSIGHT | AutomateFlow wins on usability, AI capabilities, and Velocity Systems's specific stack. IntegrateHub wins on enterprise governance and complex orchestration. For a team scaling from 200→2,000 customers with a cloud-native SaaS stack and business users building automations, AutomateFlow is the better fit. If Velocity Systems's needs shift toward heavy ERP integration or IT-controlled automation, IntegrateHub becomes more compelling.
